title: 115_s1790
content: The "Boost Saving for College Act" may be cited as the short title. It includes a credit for contributions to 529 plans. The "Boost Saving for College Act" introduces a credit for contributions to 529 plans and expands the definition of qualified savings contributions to include purchases or contributions to qualified tuition programs under certain conditions. The taxpayer, spouse, or eligible individual can make qualified savings contributions to 529 plans. Contributions are limited by the taxpayer's compensation and excluded combat pay. Adjusted gross income is used to determine eligibility. Adjusted gross income is increased by the excess of social security benefits received over the amount included in gross income for the year. The text amends various sections of the Code related to retirement savings, including changing "qualified retirement savings" to "qualified savings" and updating section headings and references. The table of sections for subpart A of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code is amended by replacing the item for section 25B with a new item. The amendments made by this section apply to contributions made after December 31, 2017, in taxable years ending after that date. Employer contributions to qualified tuition programs are excluded from gross income. The exclusion of employer contributions to qualified tuition programs from an employee's gross income is limited to $1,000 per taxable year, with adjustments for inflation starting in 2019. The exclusion of employer contributions to qualified tuition programs from an employee's gross income is limited to $1,000 per taxable year, with adjustments for inflation starting in 2019. For a qualified tuition assistance program, the employer must have a separate written plan for employees, spouses, or other individuals, with matching contributions to qualified tuition programs. The exclusion of employer contributions to qualified tuition programs from an employee's gross income is limited to $1,000 per taxable year, with adjustments for inflation starting in 2019. A qualified tuition program allows deductions for an employee or spouse who can authorize distributions and administer the account. The program must meet requirements similar to those of section 127(b). Definitions and special rules apply, with terms like 'qualified tuition program' and 'employee' having specific meanings. The text discusses the definition of 'employer' in relation to section 127(c) and the application of rules similar to section 127(c). It also mentions amendments to various sections of the Code to include references to section 127A. Additionally, there are updates to reporting and recordkeeping requirements in section 6039D and other conforming amendments in sections 125(f), 414(n)(3)(C), and 414(t)(2). Amendments are made to various sections of the Code to include references to section 127A, allowing for exclusion of certain employer-paid amounts from an employee's gross income. Section 209(a)(15) of the Social Security Act is amended to include references to section 127A, allowing for exclusion of certain employer-paid amounts from an employee's gross income. The amendments made by section 127A regarding employer contributions to qualified tuition programs will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2017. Additionally, there is a special rollover option to a Roth IRA from a long-term qualified tuition program outlined in section 4. The amendment allows for a special rollover to a Roth IRA from a long-term qualified tuition program after a 10-year period. The amendment permits a rollover to a Roth IRA from a qualified tuition program after 10 years, with certain limitations on the distribution amount. The amendment allows for rollovers from a qualified tuition program to a Roth IRA, with restrictions on the distribution amount, effective for distributions after December 31, 2017. SEC. 5. ROLLOVERS TO ABLE PROGRAMS FROM 529 PROGRAMS. This section allows for rollovers from 529 programs to ABLE accounts, with restrictions on the contribution amount, effective for distributions after the date of the enactment of this Act.
